image.altText: A graphic showing the silhouette of a man's head in front of a large eye.

props.synopsis: After Queensland passed new legislation, the Northern Territory is now the only jurisdiction in Australia where alleged sexual offenders cannot be publicly named until they are committed to stand trial.

title.children: 'Behind the times': NT becomes last jurisdiction with laws protecting the identities of alleged rapists

image.altText: A police officer has his back to the camera as he walks towards some police tape.

props.synopsis: Ronald Martin and Jeremy Scrutton pleaded guilty to fatally stabbing the man with a "butcher-style knife", during an attack at an Alice Springs home in June 2020.

title.children: Pair plead guilty to manslaughter over fatal stabbing of Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's nephew

image.altText: woman runs in shade on Sydney beach

props.synopsis: A record spell of September heat is baking southern states, with temperatures as much as 18 degrees Celsius above average.

title.children: A cool change is coming to south-eastern Australia — but it will get even hotter first

image.altText: Court staff and a protective services officer carry the Big Orange painting wrapped in plastic into a truck.

props.synopsis: In 2007, a gallery assistant made a discovery that rocked the Australian art world and led to one of the most controversial, high-profile and enduring art mysteries.

title.children: How one of Australia's most controversial art mysteries unfolded

image.altText: A 3D printed oil pump jack in front of the OPEC logo.

props.synopsis: OPEC has run an oil cartel for decades, but as the world moves away from fossil fuels, could its influence be waning, asks Nassim Khadem.

title.children: '$4.7b in profits a day': A powerful cartel still controls the world's oil and is why you're paying more for petrol

image.altText: A hand holding a fuel nozzle putting petrol in a white car

props.synopsis: People are feeling the pinch around the country as national average petrol prices top 204.4 cents per litre. But where are you at in the price cycle?

title.children: With school holidays imminent for some, will petrol prices drop any time soon? Your capital city breakdown

image.altText: Russell Brand

props.synopsis: They're allegations even the most beloved of Hollywood A-Listers would struggle to explain away, but Russell Brand and his millions of online followers exist in a different dimension, far away from cancel culture.

title.children: Why cancelling Russell Brand could be complicated

image.altText: Russell Brand leaves the Troubabour Wembley Park theatre. He is wearing sunglasses at night.

props.synopsis: A woman who accused British actor and comedian Russell Brand of sexual and emotional abuse says his denial of the allegations is "insulting".

title.children: 'Laughable and insulting': Russell Brand accuser hits out at his denials in fresh interview

image.altText: The castle at Disney World in Orlando Florida

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Extreme fire danger declared for NSW south coast, and black bear captured after shutting down Disney World rides. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An apparently hungry black bear forced a brief shutdown of some attractions at Disney World's Magic Kingdom in Florida, US, until it was captured, officials say. Local television station Fox 35 says more than a dozen popular rides at the Orlando theme park were closed after the bear was sighted in a tree, including the Haunted Mansion and Pirates of the Caribbean rides. Lisa Thompson, a spokesperson for the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission, said in a statement that the bear was likely searching for food in the area. "During the fall, bears are more active as they search for food to pack on fat reserves for the winter," she said. "In most cases, it is best for bears to be given space and to move along on their own. "But given this situation, staff have captured the animal and are relocating the bear out of the park to an area in or around the Ocala National Forest."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Black bear captured after shutting down Disney World rides

children.content: Walt Disney World is one of the largest tourist attractions in the world.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An unusually well-preserved dinosaur skeleton named "Barry" is expected to fetch up to 1.2 million euros ($2.1 million) at a Paris auction next month. The 150 million-year-old Camptosaurus was discovered in the 1990s in the US state of Wyoming. It was named after palaeontologist Barry James who first restored it in 2000. Italian laboratory Zoic, which acquired "Barry" last year, has done further restoration work on the skeleton. Alexandrew Giquello, from the auction house Hotel Drouot, says it is unusual to see a dinosaur skeleton so intact. "To take the example of its skull, the skull is complete at 90 per cent and the rest of the dinosaur is complete at 80 per cent," he says. Giquello says dinosaur specimens on the art market remain rare, with no more than a couple of sales a year worldwide.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rare dinosaur 'Barry' up for sale at Paris auction

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A total fire ban has been declared for the NSW south coast and Greater Sydney region today, with temperatures forecast to reach 33C. Angus Hines from the Bureau of Meteorology says Wednesday will be hotter at 34C, and that parts of South Australia and Queensland will also feel the heat. "Most of Australia is sitting at moderate or high fire [danger] for the next few days," he says. "The south coast of NSW has a small area of extreme fire danger there, overlapping with the heatwave conditions on Tuesday." It's the first total fire ban for Greater Sydney since late 2020, NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) spokesman Ben Shepherd says. The NSW Education Department has listed 20 schools that will be closed across the state's south coast today. The fire ban and school closures apply across areas that include the Bega Valley and Eurobodalla Shire. RFS Commissioner Rob Rogers says people need to be prepared. "It's the worst risk we've faced since the Black Summer fires of 2019," he says. The heat is expected to shift north later in the week into parts of Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia, driving maximums to 40C .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Extreme fire danger on NSW south coast forces schools to close

image.altText: A car parked next to a football pitch. Police tape is stretched across part of the area. Several police are on the pitch.

props.synopsis: ACT police confirm two 20-year-old female students are in hospital after a stabbing at the Australian National University in Canberra.

title.children: Two students in hospital after stabbing at Australian National University

image.altText: Montara well head platform continues to burn

props.synopsis: In waters around Australia's coastline are about 1 million tonnes of pipelines, moorings, fixed rigs and floating vessels. Many are due for "decommissioning" and operators are contractually obliged to remediate the sites. But the cost is gargantuan, and not everyone wants to pay, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: 'The clock is ticking': Is ageing offshore oil and gas infrastructure an environmental risk?

image.altText: A composite image of a Triton unmanned surveillance aircraft and a P-8 Poseidon

props.synopsis: Australia will upgrade its fleet of P-8 patrol aircraft so they can eventually fire missiles out to 1,000 kilometres, while also purchasing another long-range Triton drone from the United States.

title.children: P-8A Poseidon upgrade and fourth Triton drone part of $1.5b boost to RAAF

image.altText: A woman on a sporting field looking on

props.synopsis: New Spain coach Montse Tome decides to leave Jenni Hermoso out of her Nations League squad, as a possible boycott still looms.

title.children: Jenni Hermoso left out of Spanish football squad as new coach takes charge for Nations League

image.altText: Healthy juvenile wombat underneath a parent.

props.synopsis: It's barely detectable to the human eye, but a microscopic parasite has decimated wombat populations across south-east Australia. Now, researchers have a better idea of how outbreaks occur, as they continue working to find ways to rescue the iconic marsupial from a "horrible, slow death".

title.children: New research offers insights into how a deadly disease devastated a wombat population

image.altText: Woman smiling at camera near a bush

props.synopsis: It's an idyllic island that sits just off the coast of north Queensland, masking a dark past of subjugation, displacement and discrimination.

title.children: With social disadvantage 'spiralling out of control', many residents of this Queensland island hope a Voice will turn the tide

image.altText: Prisoners released during a prisoner swap deal between US and Iran, arrive at Doha International Airport.

props.synopsis: Five US citizens have left Iran and landed in Doha in a prisoner swap for five Iranians held in the United States, and the transfer of $US6 billion in frozen Iranian assets.

title.children: US prisoners 'finally coming home' in rare prisoner swap with Iran

image.altText: Justin Trudeau rises to make a statement in the House of Commons.

props.synopsis: Canada expels a top Indian diplomat as it investigates what Prime Minister Justin Trudeau calls credible allegations that India's government may have links to the killing in Canada of a Sikh activist.

title.children: Justin Trudeau says India could be behind killing of Canadian Sikh leader, expels top diplomat

image.altText: Abandoned cars on the main island of Tongatapu in the Kingdom of Tonga

props.synopsis: The Kingdom of Tonga looks like paradise, but its lush coconut palms nurse a hidden problem. Now, the country is preparing to deal with this car-sized problem, before it's too late.

title.children: Tonga has tens of thousands of abandoned cars. Now there's a plan to crush them and ship them home

image.altText: Li Shangfu salutes before delivering a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore

props.synopsis: Li Shangfu was only appointed defence minister six months ago but has become the second missing Chinese minister in two months after Qin Gang was stripped of the foreign minister portfolio, with questions of loyalty and corruption believed to behind his apparent ouster.

title.children: Where is Li Shangfu? China's defence minister has been missing for three weeks

image.altText: Gold Coast Mayor Tom Tate speaks to the media

props.synopsis: The Councillor Conduct Tribunal finds Tom Tate used ratepayer funds for two annual NRL club memberships and was reimbursed for donations in breach of the City of Gold Coast's expenses policy.

title.children: Gold Coast mayor charged ratepayers for Titans membership and engaged in misconduct, council watchdog finds

image.altText: A manicured hand holds a mobile phone in a black and white graphic.

props.synopsis: A NSW woman bugged by her spurned ex-lover describes feeling like she was in a film during the ordeal — and experts say her experience is not uncommon as offenders get better at using technology "as a weapon against women".

title.children: Stalking victim felt like she was 'in a Netflix movie', amid spike in tech-assisted tracking

image.altText: Young man with medium length brown hair and sunglasses smiling with his arms up.

props.synopsis: As a landmark study finds 4 per cent of suicides are gambling-related, a family speaks out about the impact gambling had on their son, who also had depression and suicided 12 years ago.

title.children: Jake had his whole life ahead of him, until a penchant for gambling took control

image.altText: Bert Boere holding an air pollution report standing next to Chair of the group Carmen Largaiolli.

props.synopsis: Brooklyn has some of the highest rates of pollution and residents fear the proposed facility could make that worse.

title.children: A Melbourne suburb with one of the worst pollution rates in the country fights to stop a proposed facility to treat contaminated soil

image.altText: Joe Marler talks to the referee

props.synopsis: This week, the Rugby World Cup featured an "unbelievable" gesture from the All Blacks, a Samoan with a sentimental request and some odd kit combinations. Here's what we learned from week two.

title.children: Joe Marler's magic mohawk, unusual kit clashes and an 'unbelievable' gesture: How week two of the Rugby World Cup shaped up

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: A Canberra court hears details of a series of burglaries — including the theft of two French bulldogs, several Audis and other cars — involving two 20-year-old men, one of whom allegedly joked he was taking one of the dogs "hostage".

title.children: 'Simply reckless' men who stole two French bulldogs and several cars face Canberra court

image.altText: A butcher smiles.

props.synopsis: South Australian businesses say they're rethinking how they run their services, with the most recent round of power price hikes already taking a significant toll on customers who are cutting back on purchases.

title.children: 'Everything is going up': Small businesses struggle to keep clients as prices rise

image.altText: A woman with long brown hair in a white blazer standing in front of a Vote No poster.

props.synopsis: Leading critics of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament have gathered in Adelaide for one of the biggest No campaign events so far, with one accusing supporters of the proposal of resorting to "bullying" and "gaslighting".

title.children: Leading Voice opponent uses Adelaide gathering to hit out at Yes supporters

image.altText: Lyn Read is sitting, wearing an aqua green jumper. With her dog between her arms.

props.synopsis: It was a highly sophisticated yet common scam. One that cost Lyn Read $50,000. Money the terminal cancer patient was saving for her last days and to pay for her funeral.

title.children: Lyn Read lost $50,000 in a scam, money she needs to pay for her funeral

image.altText: A Chinese air force pilot flies a military jet in full uniform and helmet.

props.synopsis: Taiwan tells China to stop its "destructive unilateral actions" after more than 100 Chinese warplanes and nine navy ships are detected in areas around the self-ruled island.

title.children: 'High alert': Taiwan detects 103 Chinese warplanes around island

image.altText: Missing woman Tina Greer smiles as she gives a 'peace' sign with her hand in a park.

props.synopsis: There is "no doubt" a Gold Coast woman was murdered by her now dead bikie boyfriend in 2012, an inquest has heard.

title.children: The day Tina Greer went missing her bikie boyfriend's car was suspiciously clean, inquest told

props.synopsis: A fire being treated as suspicious destroys 40 cars and two trailers at an automotive business at South Kempsey on the NSW Mid North Coast.

title.children: Family automotive business devastated after suspicious fire destroys 40 cars

image.altText: Courtroom panel, headed by a sign that says Ukraine

props.synopsis: A Russian representative has told the UN's highest court that Ukraine's claims Russia abused the UN Genocide Convention to start a war between the two nations were "hopelessly flawed".

title.children: 'Hopelessly flawed': Russia launches legal attack on Ukraine in UN's top court

image.altText: A close up photo of a phone with dating apps like Tinder, Grindr and Bumble on the screen.

props.synopsis: Popular online dating platforms are being threatened with greater government regulation unless they lift their standards and improve safety for users.

title.children: Dating apps threatened with regulation unless they improve safety
